title: Public API Overview
content: Public API Overview

title: Introduction
content:
# Introduction

---

Welcome to the Hospitable Public API documentation!

Latest release of the Hospitable Public API, tagged `v2`, allows you to manage calendars, reservations, properties, and more, in a programmatic way, using conventional HTTP requests.

Latest version of our API in a nutshell:

* [RESTful](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representational_state_transfer)
* [JSON](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JSON) all the way `Content-Type: application/json`, `Accept: application/json`
* authorisation via [OAuth2](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749) (and [PAT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_access_token) for personal use)
* simple versioning via path prefix `/v2/...`
* JSON superset via includes `?include=related_resource`

### [Requests](#requests)

The Hospitable API conforms to the [REST Architectural Standards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representational_state_transfer).

Entities are represented as resources, each one with an URL and unique identifier, and can be manipulated with the `GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, `PATCH`, and `DELETE` HTTP methods. All methods except for the `POST` are [idempotent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idempotence).

### [Authentication](#authentication)

The API implements [OAuth 2.0](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749) authorisation standard.

A Hospitable User may authorise your application to make requests on their behalf.

As a Hospitable User, you may generate a [Personal Access Token](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_access_token) to make requests to the API yourself.

[More information on security.](/docs/public-api-docs/xpyjv51qyelmp-authentication)

### [Versioning](#versioning)

Resources versioning in the API follows the simple principle of version in the url, e.g. `/v2/properties`, `v3/reservations`. The data suggests this is the preferred approach by our API consumers, as clearer, easier to implement, and maintain in the future.

[More information on versioning.](/docs/public-api-docs/adb5d9fe6500b-api-versioning)

### [Including Resources](#including-resources)

Certain endpoints allow including related Resources - look for `Allowed Includes` in the documentation of each endpoint. This approach might be preferred to save you from making a multiple request to build the dataset you need.

[More information on including resources.](/docs/public-api-docs/465fd4d45e4b3-including-resources)

[Introduction](#introduction "Introduction")[Requests](#requests "Requests")[Authentication](#authentication "Authentication")[Versioning](#versioning "Versioning")[Including Resources](#including-resources "Including Resources")

title: Authentication
content:
# Authentication

---

Hospitable protects our API endpoints using Personal Access Tokens, and [OAuth 2.0](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749)'s Authorization flow grants. Depending on your application use case, it might depend which authentication grant you choose to go with.

### [What Authentication should I use?](#what-authentication-should-i-use)

There are 2 forms of authentication to use the Hospitable API. Here's a short rundown on when you'd use either:

* [OAuth Authorization flow for Vendors.](#oauth-authorization-for-vendors)
  + Like when logging into a website with Google or Twitter, Hospitable has it's own OAuth2 Authorization flow. This allows any third-party to integrate directly with Hospitable, without requiring the user to manually share credentials insecurely. This has the added bonus of being extra secure for both Hospitable users, and developers wishing to build on our platform.
* [Personal Access Tokens (PATs) for Personal API use.](#personal-access-tokens)
  + As the name suggests, typically used for Personal API access. These tokens are scoped to your Hospitable account only, and should not be shared with any third-parties. You should only use these tokens for building and testing **your own** Hospitable integration.

If you require any further information on which grant better suits your use case, [get in touch with support](mailto:support@hospitable.com).

## [OAuth Authorization for Vendors](#oauth-authorization-for-vendors)

If you intend on building a Hospitable integration for others, you'll need to use our OAuth2 Authorization code flow. This follows the OAuth2 standard, which you can [learn more about here](https://www.oauth.com/oauth2-servers/access-tokens/authorization-code-request/).

#### [Applying to become an Approved Vendor](#applying-to-become-an-approved-vendor)

To get started, you'll need to request your own Vendor client credentials [via this form](https://form.typeform.com/to/n8bZPJIm). You'll be required to provide a:

* Technical point of contact
* Name and description of your app and the planned integration with Hospitable
* Requested scopes
* Hosted URL for your app's logo (in square format) - .png or .jpg
* A customer-facing description of what your app will do, this displays to the user
* A redirection URL (this should be inside your app, where you will handle the provided OAuth authorize code)
* A webhooks URL (where you'll receive all webhooks)

> ❗ We are **NOT** accepting applications for certain categories of vendors, including AI Chatbots!

You can typically expect a response to your application within a few days. We may reach out for more information.

Once your request is approved, you will be given access to our [Partner Portal](V2/Partner-Portal.md) where you can generate your client credentials, set redirect URLs and add webhook URLs.

---

### [Two ways to initiate the connection with your app](#two-ways-to-initiate-the-connection-with-your-app)

There are 2 ways a user can initiate the connection:

**One-click OAuth initiated in Hospitable by a logged-in user**

Once you have enabled OAuth, we will publish a dedicated page for your product in our [Apps marketplace](https://my.hospitable.com/apps). A logged in user will be able to initiate the connection through a Get Started button on this page.

This redirects them directly to your configured redirect URL with an authorization `code` added as a parameter to the URL. This eliminates the step where they have to be brought to a new page where they click to authorize the connection.

**Standard OAuth flow initiated by your customer from your app**

This is initiated in your app. You must bring the user to the Hospitable Authorization page, where they will be asked to login and then click to authorize the connection.

---

### [1. Setting your redirect URL](#1-setting-your-redirect-url)

When you create your client credentials in the Partner Portal, you will be able to configure the redirect URL, where we will send your customers after they have authorized the connection between your app and their Hospitable account.

By default, this URL is used for both methods described above. If you wish to set a different URL for the one-click connection, let our team know and we can configure that for you.

You also have the option to set a custom URL for the one-click connection. We will not pass the authorization code, which means the user will simply be brought to your site, and you will need to navigate them at some point to the Hospitable Authorization page, following the standard flow. The custom URL supports state so you can associate the request with the user.

### [2. Setting up the OAuth flow](#2-setting-up-the-oauth-flow)

#### [a. Lead the user to authorize the connection](#a-lead-the-user-to-authorize-the-connection)

> This step is skipped if the customer initiates the connection from Hospitable's side using the One-click OAuth. Upon redirect to your page, we will pass the code which you can already use to request for the tokens in step by step.

You will need to create a button or link within your app that redirects your user to the Hospitable Authorization page:

```


https://auth.hospitable.com/oauth/authorize?client_id=<your vendor id>&response_type=code


```

The `response_type=code` tells the authorization server that the application is initiating the authorization code flow which is an [OAuth 2.0 grant type](https://developer.okta.com/blog/2018/04/10/oauth-authorization-code-grant-type). Note: the `code` is a string, and not a placeholder to be replaced with any value.

> 💡 Use the state parameter to associate an authorization request to a customer
>
> You can optionally add the `?state=<string>` parameter to the authorization URL which, in addition to adding a layer of security, allows you to identify the source of the request, e.g. identify the customer that just completed the flow.
> The `state` value will passed back to you by adding it to your the redirect URL, which you can compare with the value you stored earlier.
>
> [Learn more about it here.](https://auth0.com/docs/secure/attack-protection/state-parameters)

The Hospitable Authorization page will initially present them with a login page. (this will always be presented as long as they initiated from your page, even if they were already logged in to Hospitable in the same browser session). After providing their credentials, they will be asked to Authorize the connection with your app.

#### [b. Handle the redirect](#b-handle-the-redirect)

When the user clicks "Authorize" they'll be redirected to the URL that you configured in the Partner Portal. There will be an authorization `code` added as a parameter to the URL.

https://not-hospitable.com/redirect?code=def2020087...

This will also include the `state` if you had provide that earlier.

#### [c. Request for the access token](#c-request-for-the-access-token)

Make a request to our OAuth2 server at `https://auth.hospitable.com/oauth/token`, providing your client credentials, `"authorization_code"` grant type and the provided `code` from the redirection.

The request should look like this:

```


curl --request POST \



--url https://auth.hospitable.com/oauth/token \



--header 'Content-Type: application/json' \



--data '{



"client_id": "<your vendor id>",



"client_secret": "<your vendor secret>",



"grant_type": "authorization_code",



"code": "def5020087..."



}'


```

With a response of:

```


{



"token_type": "Bearer",



"expires_in": 43200,



"access_token": "eyJ0eXA...",



"refresh_token": "def502005..."



}


```

Once you have the `access_token`, you can start making API requests on behalf of the user by including it in the Authorization header of each request:

```


curl --request GET \



--url https://public.api.hospitable.com/properties \



--header 'Authorization: Bearer <token>'


```

> 🚧 **Token validity**
>
> The `access_token` expires after 12 hours. You will need to request for new access tokens using the `refresh_token`.
>
> 📘 **Check your database columns!**
>
> Tokens are quite large! Access tokens ~1,200 chars and Refresh tokens ~1,000 chars respectively. If your database columns aren't configured correctly, you might experience unexpected issues with accessing the API, or refreshing due to truncation.

### [Refreshing your access tokens](#refreshing-your-access-tokens)

When the access token expires, you'll receive a `401 Unauthenticated` error from your API requests. To resolve this, you'll need to refresh your access using the `refresh_token` that was also provided in the authorization response.

The refresh request looks like this:

```


curl --request POST \



--url https://auth.hospitable.com/oauth/token \



--header 'Content-Type: application/json' \



--data '{



"client_id": "<your vendor id>",



"client_secret": "<your vendor secret>",



"grant_type": "refresh_token",



"refresh_token": "<the refresh token>"



}'


```

This will provide a response identical step 3 when you first requested the tokens. The response will provide you with a new set of access\_token and refresh\_token.

> 🚧 Refresh tokens expire!
>
> If your integration doesn't refresh Access Tokens immediately after expiry (which is common in some use cases where you may not need constant API access), you'll need to be careful - **Refresh Tokens expire after 90 days**. We recommend refreshing all tokens on a regular interval to ensure Hosts don't need to keep re-authorising your application.

---

## [Personal Access Tokens for Hospitable users](#personal-access-tokens-for-hospitable-users)

If you're just trying to play around with your Hospitable account programatically, or have an existing system built to automate your workflows, you can use Personal Access Tokens which provides the same access to endpoints as vendors.

> 📘 Choose the right grant!
>
> If you're building a Hospitable integration to be used by others, you will need to use our [OAuth2 Authorization flow](#oauth-authorization-for-vendors). We do not recommend storing other users' Personal Access Tokens.

To get started with Personal Access Tokens, start by logging into your Hospitable account and visiting your [API keys](https://my.hospitable.com/apps/api-keys) section in the apps settings.

Once there, you can create and manage your Personal Access Tokens. Click "+ Add new" in the top right to create a new one, giving it any name you'd like:

![](https://files.readme.io/a2b24de-image.png)

This is the only step required to gain authentication for your account. Now, any requests you make to our API should include the `Authorization` header, with `Bearer <token>` as the value.

```


curl --request GET \



--url https://public.api.hospitable.com/v2/properties \



--header 'Accept: application/json' \



--header 'Authorization: Bearer <token>' \



--header 'Content-Type: '


```

[Authentication](#authentication "Authentication")[What Authentication should I use?](#what-authentication-should-i-use "What Authentication should I use?")[OAuth Authorization for Vendors](#oauth-authorization-for-vendors "OAuth Authorization for Vendors")[Two ways to initiate the connection with your app](#two-ways-to-initiate-the-connection-with-your-app "Two ways to initiate the connection with your app")[1. Setting your redirect URL](#1-setting-your-redirect-url "1. Setting your redirect URL")[2. Setting up the OAuth flow](#2-setting-up-the-oauth-flow "2. Setting up the OAuth flow")[Refreshing your access tokens](#refreshing-your-access-tokens "Refreshing your access tokens")[Personal Access Tokens for Hospitable users](#personal-access-tokens-for-hospitable-users "Personal Access Tokens for Hospitable users")

title: Versioning
content:
# API Versioning

The Hospitable API uses a major version number in the URL (e.g. `/v2/`). This version number will only change when we make breaking changes to the API.

Breaking changes include:

* Removing fields
* Changing field types
* Changing response formats
* Removing endpoints

When we need to make breaking changes, we'll release a new major version. The old version will continue to work for a period of time to allow you to migrate your integration.

## [Sunset Notices](#sunset-notices)

When an API version is scheduled for retirement, we'll communicate this in two ways:

1. Through our documentation and email notifications
2. Through HTTP headers in API responses

### [HTTP Headers](#http-headers)

When using an API version that is scheduled for sunset, you'll receive the following headers in the response:

```


Sunset: 2025-02-03



Link: <https://developer.hospitable.com/docs/public-api-docs/upgrade-guide>; rel="sunset"


```

After the sunset date, you may be automatically upgraded to the most recent version as we remove the old endpoint.

Our API Versioning is endpoint-specific, allowing us to update the version number of one endpoint without changing the others. This allows you to update your integration one endpoint at a time, rather than having to do them all in one go.

## [Best Practices](#best-practices)

1. Always check response headers for sunset notices
2. Monitor the warnings in the response metadata
3. Plan your migration well before the sunset date
4. Test your integration thoroughly with the new version before switching

[API Versioning](#api-versioning "API Versioning")[Sunset Notices](#sunset-notices "Sunset Notices")[HTTP Headers](#http-headers "HTTP Headers")[Best Practices](#best-practices "Best Practices")

title: Webhooks
content:
# Webhooks

---

We will always send POST requests to your URL and expect a 200 response status code. Other responses or lack thereof will cause webhook re-tries.

### [Payload fields](#payload-fields)

When you receive a webhook from us, you can safely assume that each payload contains at least the following fields:

| Key | Type | Description | Example |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| id | ULID (string) | A unique ordered ID assigned to the payload of the webhook. | 01GTKD6ZYFVQMR0RWP4HBBHNZC |
| data | object OR array of objects | JSON object relevant to the given action. Structure will be the same as making a GET request to a relevant endpoint. |  |
| action | string | The action that informs you the cause of this webhook | reservation.changed |
| created | UTC Zulu ISO8601 String | When the payload was initially created | 2023-10-01T09:35:24Z |
| version | string | Version of the webhook | 1.0 |

### [v1 to v2 field mapping](#v1-to-v2-field-mapping)

As part of our upgrade to the v2 API, we have updated some of the fields in the webhook payload.
You can find the table comparing the fields on our [upgrade guide](https://developer.hospitable.com/docs/public-api-docs/upgrade-guide#webhook-field-mapping).

### [Retries](#retries)

If your webhook handler does not respond with a `200 OK` we will retry it up to 5 times or until successful response, with exponential back-off: `1 sec, 5 sec, 10 sec, 1 hr, 6 hr`

### [IP range](#ip-range)

Our webhooks will be sent from the following IP range `38.80.170.0/24`. You are advised to whitelist only this IP for your webhook handler for better security.

### [Signature](#signature)

We will include a `Signature` header in each webhook call. You can use this field to verify that Hospitable is the sender and the payload has not changed.

To do this you need the following:

* Payload
* Webhook secret

> 🤫 **Obtaining your secret:**
>
> If you are a Vendor then you can manage your webhooks and secrets from within your [partner portal](/docs/public-api-docs/03fvv8cmnjlqw-partner-portal).
>
> If you are a host, your secret will be the primary user's email address encoded in base64.

We sign the webhook using the standard HMAC with the SHA256 function.

For example:

* Payload is `{"foo": "bar"}`
* Your webhook secret is "123456"
* The signature header `cc99bf5947391ddb0d0d9866f5b9d3a68e8b273c5ac8f699b4ae2399a7433118`

You can now apply the HMAC to verify

```


function verify(string $payload, string $signature): bool



{



$expected = hash_hmac('sha256', $payload, env('SECRET', '123456'));



return hash_equals($expected, $signature);



}


```

## [Information for Vendors](#information-for-vendors)

### [Webhook URLs](#webhook-urls)

The URLs are not to be configured inside your customer's Hospitable account.

We will send webhooks for all of your customers to the URLs you have configured in your Partner Portal.

### [Historical webhooks](#historical-webhooks)

You can request our platform team to re-send webhooks generated within a date range and optionally filter by property. Send a message to [team-platform@hospitable.com](mailto:team-platform@hospitable.com).

### [Channel scoping](#channel-scoping)

It is not possible to assign a URL for specific channels.

[Webhooks](#webhooks "Webhooks")[Payload fields](#payload-fields "Payload fields")[v1 to v2 field mapping](#v1-to-v2-field-mapping "v1 to v2 field mapping")[Retries](#retries "Retries")[IP range](#ip-range "IP range")[Signature](#signature "Signature")[Information for Vendors](#information-for-vendors "Information for Vendors")[Webhook URLs](#webhook-urls "Webhook URLs")[Historical webhooks](#historical-webhooks "Historical webhooks")[Channel scoping](#channel-scoping "Channel scoping")

title: Reference

title: Http Responses
content:
# HTTP Responses

---

### [HTTP Status Codes](#http-status-codes)

The Hospitable Public API returns [HTTP Status Codes](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status) with every response, including error codes. All being well, you should expect to see status codes in the 200 range alongside your responses.

In the event of a problem, the status code is a reliable indicator of what went wrong. Return codes in the `400` range indicate that there was an issue with the request that was sent, and you may need to change the request, update the code, or data on your end.

Status codes in the `500` range may mean that either we or a provider (e.g. Airbnb or HomeAway/VRBO) are experiencing an issue. In this case you will most likely need to retry the request after our systems are back in shape - check our [Status Page](https://status.hospitable.com/) for more information on that.

### [Response Body Format](#response-body-format)

The Hospitable API responds in JSON format adhering to the following JSON Schema:

```


# multiple paginated results



{



"data": [



{...},



{...}



],



"meta": {



"current_page" : 1,



"last_page" : 10,



"per_page" : 10,



"from" : 1,



"to" : 10,



"total" : 100,



"links" : {...}



}


```

> 📘 Includes
>
> See Pagination for more information on paginating results.

```


# single result



{



"data": {



#...



}



}


```

A further explanation of this schema:

* `data`: The requested data, either as an entity or array of entities (if multiple were requested).
* `meta`: Further information alongside the request, possibly including links to other resources, pagination details, and any warnings (e.g. if a deprecated version of the resource was requested).

> 📘 Includes
>
> See Including Resources for more information on requesting a superset JSON result of a resource.

### [Unique request ID](#unique-request-id)

Every response from the Public API contains an `X-hospitable-trace` header which provides the unique ID given to the request:

X-hospitable-trace: 'b4bc88fd9b8446768bde07864e6ee263'

[HTTP Responses](#http-responses "HTTP Responses")[HTTP Status Codes](#http-status-codes "HTTP Status Codes")[Response Body Format](#response-body-format "Response Body Format")[Unique request ID](#unique-request-id "Unique request ID")

title: Pagination
Including Resources
content:
# Including Resources

---

In some cases, it's possible to request a superset of data to be returned. These are labelled as `Allowed Includes` in the documentation. Using this may save you from making a second API request to get more information.

In order to do this, add a URL parameter of `include` to your request. For example, when requesting Reservations, it's possible to include data on the Guest without having to make separate HTTP requests by adding `include=guest` as a URL parameter:

```


GET /reservations/c9bc3e39-4275-4199-944c-cf52079903f9?include=guest


```

This will embed the included resource in the API response, under an `guest` key. For example:

```


{



"data": {



"id": "c9bc3e39-4275-4199-944c-cf52079903f9",



"platform_id": "AHDKVUCXXXM",



"guest": {



"email": "...",



"phone_numbers": ["..."],



"first_name": "...",



"last_name": "..."



}



}



}


```

### [Multiple includes](#multiple-includes)

The following formats are accepted for including multiple objects:

* `?include[]=listings&include[]=details&include[]=bookings`
* `?include=listings,details,bookings`

[Including Resources](#including-resources "Including Resources")[Multiple includes](#multiple-includes "Multiple includes")

title: Enums & Statuses
content:
In this section you will find available enumerations to help you handle different cases in your implementation.

**NOTE** We are constantly improving our APIs, enabling new functionalities, and new platforms. There might be cases of new items appearing in the lists in the future. Inform us if you spot such situations to help us improve together.

## [Reservation statuses](#reservation-statuses)

| category | sub\_category | Description |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `request` | `pending verification` | A request to book is in process, but is awaiting verification completion on the guest's side. |
|  | `request to book` | A request to book that has not been actioned yet. |
|  | `request for payment` | A request for payment, made by the host and awaiting guest response. |
|  |  |  |
| `accepted` | `null` | An Accepted reservation without a more granular status assigned. |
|  |  |  |
| `cancelled` | `null` | A Cancelled reservation without a more granular status assigned. |
|  |  |  |
| `not accepted` | `declined` | An Inquiry or Request that was Declined by the host. |
|  | `withdrawn` | An Inquiry or Request that was withdrawn by the guest. |
|  | `expired` | The request was not actioned in time. |
|  |  |  |
| `unknown` |  | This can mean that the reservation is in a broken state, or the status is newly implemented by the booking platform that isn't internally recognized yet. |

[On this page](# "On this page")[Reservation statuses](#reservation-statuses "Reservation statuses")

title: Calendar Restriction
content:
# Calendar Restriction

Hospitable has two types of integrations with Airbnb: [limited Operations scope](https://help.hospitable.com/en/articles/8889941-using-other-software-alongside-airbnb) and the [full PMS scope](https://help.hospitable.com/en/articles/9853198-new-upgraded-airbnb-connectivity).

### [Core/Public API](#corepublic-api)

For customers that are on the PMS scope, their calendars can be updated through the Public API.

For customers whose Airbnb accounts are downgraded to the Operations scope, it will not be possible to update their Hospitable calendar. Update Property Calendar PUT requests will return a `status_code: 422`with `reason_phrase: This property has a channel that is calendar restricted, and updates can not be made to the calendar`. Customers will only be able to update their calendar directly on Airbnb.

### [Connect API](#connect-api)

Only the Operations scope is offered for the Connect API. It is possible to update the Airbnb calendar prices for your customers through the Connect API.

### [How this affects our mutual customers](#how-this-affects-our-mutual-customers)

If you have a customer on Connect that becomes a Hospitable user and then connects their Airbnb channel to Hospitable, their channel will remain connected on Connect but your write abilities to their calendar will change, depending on which API you continue to use to manage the user's calendar.

| Customer type | Integration | Connection scope | Modify pricing | Modify availability |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Your customers | Hospitable Connect | Limited connection | YES | NO |
| Your mutual customers with Hospitable | Hospitable Connect | Limited connection | NO | NO |
| Your mutual customers with Hospitable | Hospitable Core via Public API | Limited connection | NO | NO |
| Your mutual customers with Hospitable | Hospitable Core via Public API | Full connection | YES | YES |

If you wish to manage the availabilities for customers who are on the limited scope, you can generate an iCal which they can import in their Airbnb listing provided they aren't already using another PMS with Airbnb.

[Calendar Restriction](#calendar-restriction "Calendar Restriction")[Core/Public API](#corepublic-api "Core/Public API")[Connect API](#connect-api "Connect API")[How this affects our mutual customers](#how-this-affects-our-mutual-customers "How this affects our mutual customers")

title: Inquiry Resource
content:
# Inquiry Resource

Clarifications are in order with regards to the inquiry entity and how it relates to conversations and reservations in the Hospitable system.

> There is no inquiry entity itself. There are only `conversation` and `reservation` resources, and 'inquiry' is simply the status of a conversation.

The `conversation` is the fundamental resource, to which a `reservation` **can** be attached. Conversations are what live in the Hospitable Inbox; in a way, they are what *contain* the reservation.

When the first message from a new guest comes in (and which is **not** an instant booking nor a booking request), a `conversation` record is created in our system. The **conversation status** is set to `Inquiry`. When the inquiry turns into a confirmed booking, then a `reservation` record is created.

> Individual messages are their own resource type; they are not inquiry entities.

For instant bookings or booking requests that come in, both `conversation` record and `reservation` record are created at the same time.

Having defined that, you can associate the messages always to a `conversation` (the `conversation_id` is always present in a message webhook), and then to a reservation if one exists for it (which naturally means the message should have come with the `reservation_id`, otherwise it is `null`).

It is a good idea to implement the same resource structure on your end. That way when you receive these pre-booking messages, they aren't orphan entities.

## [Inquiry endpoints](#inquiry-endpoints)

As a matter of convention, the [Get Inquiries](https://developer.hospitable.com/docs/public-api-docs/9lujw5cgctxti-get-inquries) and [Send Message for Inquiry](https://developer.hospitable.com/docs/public-api-docs/74f2albwvbvyq-send-message-for-inquiry) endpoints are named as such since these will only provide you with (and allow you to send messages to) **conversations** that have no `reservation_id` attached.

The uuid

title: Partner Portal
content:
# Partner Portal

Vendors are granted access to the Partner Portal which provides logs of webhooks and API requests and the ability to configure webhooks and clients.

The portal is found on <https://partners.hospitable.com/>.

If you don't have access yet, you can reach out to the Platform team at [team-platform@hospitable.com](mailto:team-platform@hospitable.com) for an invitation to be sent to you. Note that the invitation link to create your password expires after some time. If it has expired for you, you can create your password instead through the [password reset page](https://partners.hospitable.com/password-reset/request).

### [Adding users](#adding-users)

Multiple users can be added upon request to our team. All users have the same access/permission level within your account in the Portal.

> If you have access to both Public API and Connect, you can switch views using the dropdown on the top-right.

## [Public API view](#public-api-view)

In **Settings**, the user can:

* **Create OAuth clients to generate your credentials and set your redirect URL**
  + As soon as you create one, the client secret will be provided to you. Copy this and securely store is it will no longer be viewable later.
  + Clicking on the Edit icon beside the client allows you to modify your redirect URL.
  + You can create multiple clients for development, staging, production, etc. Clicking on the 3 dots beside the client allows you to **mark it as the Production client**. *This is helpful for our team to identify the proper client in case you need us to update something.*
* **Configure webhook URLs and triggers**
* Upload your company/app logo which will be used on the end-user connection flow. The URL must point directly to the hosted image. It must be in square format (.png or .jpg).
* See your currently **connected users** (which includes their customer uuids and status of their token)
  + We display all users with an active OAuth token, whether or not their refresh token is still valid (i.e. not expired).

## [Connect view](#connect-view)

In **Settings**, the user can:

* Create access tokens
  + The access token is displayed only once, so make sure to copy and securely store this.
* Add webhook URLs

### [Logs](#logs)

The **Webhooks** page provides logs of webhooks attempted to be sent to the vendor, including the response and error codes. An individual log page provides the payload as well as the **Share** link which points to the webhook log on the Portal. This can be useful when reporting issues.

The **API requests** page provides logs of the requests made by the vendor on the API, including the response and error codes. A **Share** button is also available for each log. Additionally, there is a **copy to curl** button which copies the full curl request to clipboard.

[Partner Portal](#partner-portal "Partner Portal")[Adding users](#adding-users "Adding users")[Public API view](#public-api-view "Public API view")[Connect view](#connect-view "Connect view")[Logs](#logs "Logs")

Provide your bearer token in the Authorization header when making requests to protected resources.

# Generate a quote

> 📘 **Scopes required**:

title: Get Reservations
content:
# Get Reservations

get

https://public.api.hospitable.com/v2/reservations

> 📘 **Available includes**:
>
> * guest
> * user
> * financials (required: `financials:read` scope)
> * listings (required: `listing:read` scope)
> * properties (required: `property:read` scope)
> * review (required: `reviews:read` scope)

> We will default to reservations with check-in dates in the next 2 weeks if at least one of these query parameters are not provided:
>
> * `start_date`
> * `end_date`
> * `date_query`

## [Request](#Request)

Security: Bearer Auth

### [Query Parameters](#Query-Parameters)

properties[]

array[string]

required

Array of property UUIDs to query for.

Example:

?properties[]=1234&properties[]=6789

conversation\_id

string

Find reservations with a conversation id that exactly matches the one given

date\_query

string

Configure whether to use your date values to search by 'checkin' or 'checkout'.

Default:

checkin

end\_date

string<date>

Find reservations with check-in/check-out dates before this day.

Example:

2020-02-28

Match pattern:

\d{4}-\d{2}-\d{2}

include

string

Comma-separated values, any of: financials,financialsV2,guest,properties,listings

last\_message\_at

string<date-time>

Find reservations where the last message is after the specified datetime

Example:

2024-01-01 12:00:00

Match pattern:

\d{4}-\d{2}-\d{2} \d{2}:\d{2}:\d{2}

page

integer<int32>

The page number you would like to retrieve

Default:

1

per\_page

integer<int32>

The number of results to include per page.

<= 100

Default:

10

platform\_id

string

Find reservations with a reservation code that exactly matches the one given

start\_date

string<date>

Find reservations with check-in/check-out dates after this day.

Match pattern:

\d{4}-\d{2}-\d{2}

### [Headers](#request-headers)

Content-Type

string

Default:

application/json

200

required

required

Example:

string

required

airbnbhomeawaybookingdirectmanual

homeaway

string

required

Example:

string<date-time>

required

arrival\_date

required

2019-01-03T00:00:00-05:00

departure\_date

# Get Reservation by UUID

get

https://public.api.hospitable.com/v2/reservations/{uuid}

> 📘 **Available includes**:
>
> guest
> user
> financials (required: `financials:read` scope)  
> financialsV2 (required: `financials:read` scope)  
> listings (required: `listing:read` scope)  
> properties (required: `property:read` scope)

## [Request](#Request)

Security: Bearer Auth

### [Path Parameters](#Path-Parameters)

uuid

string

required

The UUID of the reservation to retrieve

### [Query Parameters](#Query-Parameters)

include

string

Comma-separated values, any of: financials,guest,properties,listings

### [Headers](#request-headers)

Content-Type

string

Default:

application/json

200

400

200

application/json

application/json

# Get Property Reviews

# Hospitable API V2 Webhooks

Export

v2.0

API Base URL

Live Server:https://public.api.hospitable.com/v2

title: Receive Reservation POST
content:
post

Reservation

> 📘 **Includes**:
>
> * guest
> * financials (required: `financials:read` scope)
> * listings (required: `listing:read` scope)
> * properties (required: `property:read` scope) - review (required: `review:read` scope)
>
> **NOTE**: Includes are added automatically based on the scopes that are enabled for your integration.

We will fire the reservation webhook when the following data is changed on a reservation:

* arrival\_date
* departure\_date
* guests
* status
* check\_in
* check\_out
* financials

## [Request](#Request)

### [Body](#request-body)

title: Receive Property Merged POST
content:
post

Property Merged

This webhook will be sent when a property is merged with another that results in one of the properties being deleted. It can be used to map any existing property id's to the new property id.

We will also send a `property.changed` webhook for the new property as its listings will have been updated.

We will not send a `property.deleted` webhook for the old property as it can be handled with this webhook.

## [Request](#Request)

### [Body](#request-body)

application/json

application/json

id

string<uuid>

data

object

string<uuid>

Example:

new\_id

string<uuid>

Example:

action

any

Allowed value:

property.merged

created

string<date-time>

Example:

2024-10-08T07:03:34Z

version

string

Example:

v2

## [Responses](#Responses)

200

Return a 200 status to indicate that the data was received successfully

title: Receive Message POST
content:
post

Message

This webhook will be sent when a new message is created in Hospitable. We will not send messages older than 12 hours, to retrieve historic messages when a new channel is connected please use the messages API.

> ❗**Beta Version**
> This webhook is a beta version. It will be subject to further development may will change in the future.

## [Request](#Request)

### [Body](#request-body)

application/json

application/json

id

string<uuid>

data

Example:

0

title: Receive Review POST
content:
post

Review

This webhook will be sent when a new review is received.

Currently, we source review data from Airbnb and our own direct bookings.

> 📘 **Includes**:
>
> * listing (required: `listings:read` scope)
> * property (required: `property:read` scope)
>
> **NOTE**: Includes are added automatically based on the scopes that are enabled for your integration.
